description:
This free, two-part program will explore the work of two environmentally conscious artists in anticipation of Ithaca's March for Science on Earth Day 2017.
https://www.facebook.com/events/1666981656927518/

“Bus Talk” at 4:30PM: Board the MossLab, the renovated RV parked in front of the Museum. Spearheaded by Marion Wilson of Syracuse University, the MossLab (or MLAB—Mobile Literacy Arts Bus) has traveled up and down the eastern seaboard with the aim of creating an archive of native mosses. Join Wilson to learn about artistic observation and drawing of native mosses, including those contained in the Museum’s own Morgan Garden.  

“Gallery Talk” at 5:15PM: Simon Norfolk’s "Stratographs" series of photographs visualize the receding Lewis Glacier on Mt. Kenya, the second highest mountain in Africa. Seven prints from this series are currently on view at the Museum. Learn more at this gallery talk with Cornell's Johannes Lehmann and the Johnson's Andrea Inselmann.

The Museum will be open Thursday until 7:30PM.

venue.about: Admission is always free! | Twitter & Instagram @HFJMuseum
venue.name: Herbert F. Johnson Museum of Art

name: Thursday at the Johnson: Artists & Ecology

description:
PRIMATE FIASCO from Northhampton, MA midway through their three month New England blowout tour will be gracing The Range's stage on Thursday April 6....

"To a deaf person, they look like a New Orleans dixieland street band. To a blind person, they sound like a rave DJ mashing-up house beats with 60′s folk lyrics. To the police, it’s a busy day on the sidewalk.

The Primate Fiasco uses instruments that are loud without electricity, giving them the opportunity to attack at any moment, in any location, with or without permission. No one is safe, not even an elevator or city bus. If The Primate Fiasco sees a dull moment somewhere, they will pop out of the nearest sewer drain or trash can to lead an irresistible dance party.

On stage, the sound is different. This band has pioneered what is possible with mind-bending Accordion, funky pockets of a hyperactive Sousaphone player, and banjo that thinks it’s a Fender Strat. Add lyrics that grab hold of even the most inattentive audience and beats that channel surf like a remote that’s been sat on. The music is always high energy and extremely imaginative. Most importantly, this is fun. People smile from the first beat to the last smoldering ash of what was previously a dance floor.

Following a Grammy-nominated kids album, several conquered jam and electronica fests and stolen hearts at prestigious folk festivals, the Primate Fiasco audience demographic is as diverse as a New York City street. No one is safe from the Fiasco. You will smile."

THE ITHACA BOTTOM BOYS have been turning heads in the local and regional scene recently due to several undeniably stellar shows at last years Grassroots Music Festival in Trumansburg, and at The Blind Spots welcome home show at The Haunt this past Saint Patricks Day. 

Delightfully disorienting in their designated "genre" the Bottom Boys do their best to keep their audiences engaged, loose, and wanting more. 

It was only this past Saturday that the IBB came home from their first shows out of NYS. The week was packed with unforgettably formative experiences, where they were given new opportunities to refine their sound and stage show to new calibers.

DOORS at 9PM, SHOW at 9:30
COVER $5

How does art intersect with crime, prisons, education, and justice? Professor Bruce Levitt from the Department of Performing and Media Arts, facilitator for the Phoenix Players Theatre Group at Auburn Correctional Facility, will lead a "Contemporary Conversation" along with members of the student organization Prison Reform and Education Project (PREP).

In association with this session, works from the Museum's collection documenting prisons and justice will be on view March 23 to April 2 in the study gallery [above, Danny Lyon (American, b. 1942), "The Line, Ferguson Unit, Texas" (detail), 1967.) 

The Museum will be open Thursday until 7:30PM.

description:
The Range welcomes Gratefully Yours Friday March 31st. Come celeabrate with one of the best Grateful Dead cover bands around! Break out your colorful tie-dyes and spend the evening listening to cultural music that has withstood the test of time.

Band Bio:

Gratefully Yours has quickly established itself as one of the Northeast’s premiere Grateful Dead cover bands; with a truly all-star lineup and often performing “dream” set lists submitted by their fans. The band was founded in 2012 by Alex Mazur, (founding member and keyboardist of The Deadbeats… one of the, if not the longest running Grateful Dead cover bands in existence).  Along with a core lineup that includes, Adam Czolowski (Sonic Garden), Tom Pirozzi (Ominous Seapods), Jeff Martinson (Shakedown) and Rob Schiff (Nailed Shutt), other honored members include Vinnie Amico (moe.), Rob Eaton (Dark Star Orchestra), Russ Lawton (Trey Anastasio Band), Bill Carbone (Max Creek) and Zach Nugent (Cats Under The Stars).
The Dead were a truly unique band and had a unique bond with their audience:  Magic is what they did. Music was how they did it. Ultimately, it is that magic that Gratefully Yours aims to “cover” and pay tribute to. And taking it one step further, they also encourage their audience to participate further in the creative process by giving them the opportunity to submit their dream set lists (or vote for one) online and the band often chooses one to perform at their shows. But of course, you never know what might happen…

      St. Vith takes a modern impression on the 70's jam styles of bands such as the grateful dead. They are tuned to a intimate setting such as wineries and cafes, though they are not limited. Festivals and larger settings allow for a fuller spectrum of intensity and sound. Ever changing with guests, and environment, St. Vith provides an eclectic original and colorful experience.

Crystal Garden comes to The Range in Ithaca on April 2, 2017, featuring band founder and Dave Matthews Band violinist, Boyd Tinsley and Mycle Wastman of TV's The Voice. Tickets are very limited and will sellout. Each ticket includes a meet and greet with Crystal  Garden including Boyd Tinsley! Don't miss this rare intimate performance with this up and coming band. Opening the show will be Vinegar Williams      

Crystal Garden is the brainchild of Boyd Tinsley of Dave Matthews Band. For two years he sought out the right group of musicians to form a modern day rock band. The four members of the band are from Seattle, San Francisco, and Toronto. Crystal Garden will soon release a CD that features Boyd Tinsley and special guest Stanley Jordan. 

The band members are Mycle Wastman, vocals, Charlie Csontos, bass, Matt Frewen, drums, 

 "Vinegar Williams is the solo project of Singer/Songwriter Chris Everson, current frontman for the Ithaca grunge rock band, Decoration Day, and formerly of Armed Uprising, CustomDriver, and 30 Watts Short."

description:
This fun-filled special monthly event features activities that are geared towards the community's older population, providing them with an opportunity to spend a day downtown participating in educational and entertaining activities while discovering or reacquainting themselves with downtown's offerings. During these colder months, Day Out will actually focus more on what's inside Downtown Ithaca!

This Month's Schedule:

10:30 AM | 365 Things to do Ithaca Ithaca - Meet the Author
Sunny Days of Ithaca 123 S. Cayuga St. 607-319-5260 
Drop in to Sunny Days of Ithaca for a casual meet-the-author discussion with author, Laurel Guy, who wrote the book 365 Days of Ithaca.  
A quirky, humours, whimsical book that weaves 10,000 details of the town, people, and even weather!  Learn more about Ithaca from Laurel and share your stories too!

12:00 PM | Lunch at Moosewood Restaurant | Dewitt Mall 215 N. Cayuga St.
This month, we'll be dining at Moosewood!  All Day Out participants will enjoy a 10% off their order, and receive a coupon for 25% off the next visit!  

1:00PM | Matinee Special at Cinemapolis | 120 E. Green St.
Back by popular demand, Cinemapolis will host a Day Out in Downtown matinee special. $6 movie tickets to any of the following movies:
The Sense of an Ending | Lion | Kedi
Moonlight | I am Not Your Negro

For more information about this special day, RSVP your attendance, and/or learn about parking options for the activity, please call the Downtown Ithaca Alliance at (607) 277-8679.

description:
An evening of singer songwriters with special guest Frank Critelli, from Connecticut. Frank will be joined by Janet Batch, Vee Da Bee, and Adrien Brodeur - showcasing a stunning diversity of our local talent. 

Frank Critelli writes songs. He dabbles in haiku and other short poetry. Sometimes he writes other stuff too. Like postcards. His songs are available on compact disc and for download at places like CD Baby. 

Frank Critelli often performs live. Sometimes he performs solo, and sometimes he is accompanied by one or more musical co-conspirators. Over the years he's played in streets and subways, clubs and coffeehouses, barrooms and classrooms, colleges, festivals, theaters, and (most recently) in his kitchen.

Frank Critelli enjoys local music scenes and the beer that goes with them, and co-hosts The Local Bands Show on 99.1fm WPLR-New Haven, and The Beer Show on CygnusRadio.com

https://www.facebook.com/Frank-Critelli-59852521448

8pm, $5

description:
This year, HEC explored change: while shifts in the industry can be unexpected or uncertain, every organization has to evolve to maintain its competitive advantage, while still honoring the values that made them successful in the past. This year’s program cuts through the anxieties of change and looks at how HEC, the Hotel School, and the hospitality industry as a whole can maintain their identities—and value—as they navigate the ever-changing business environment.

description:
Born in the woods of Connecticut and raised in the wilds of Boston, lespecial has established themselves as innovators and tastemakers on their own unique trajectory. The aggressive death-funk dance trio explodes with energetic live sets, tapping into a primitive past distorted through the lense of contemporary technology. Their debut full length album “Omnisquid”, out November 20th 2015, captures the band (at their heaviest,) interweaving dark, heavy, polyrhythmic grooves with head bobbing electronic synths and samplers augmented with fierce, precise musicianship, creating an apocalyptic backdrop for the sci-fi storyline. Preceded by their Ceremony EP (2013) and Playonbrother Sessions (2011), Jonathan Grusauskas (guitar/synth/sampler/vocals), Luke Bemand (bass/synth) and Rory Dolan (drums/sampler) ignore convention, instead amalgamating the familiar styles of Afro-Latin rhythmic traditions, Hip Hop, Funk and Metal into a singular sound that dexterously transforms during their live sets and over the course of their studio albums. As Ben Weiss of Relix Magazine puts it, “Amidst the rest of the noise, lespecial is the squeaky wheel that demands attention.”
Follow at @lespecialmusic 
http://www.lespecial.net/
http://www.lespecial.bandcamp.com/
http://www.soundcloud.com/lespecial

description:
We had to turn away so many people from last year’s Internet Cat Video Festival that we decided to offer 2 shows this year! (Fri, March 3 at 7pm & Sat, March 4 at 2pm, in Willard Straight Theatre.) Recently renamed simply Cat Video Fest and now headed up by longtime festival curator Will Braden, the creator of the Henri Le Chat Noir videos, we can’t wait to see the new reel he’s assembled that will feature approximately 100 cat videos in categories like Comedy, Drama, Animated, Musical, Action, Vintage, and Documentary. So come purrrrr on your favorites as part of this super entertaining interactive event that will include kitty cat trivia, name that kitty tune, cat masks, kitty candy and more.

Internet Cat Video expert Leah Shafer '94/'99'/'08  will return for both shows as our Mistress of Purremonies, and special guest Bruce Kornreich, Assoc. Director of the Cornell Feline Health Center, will join us on March 3rd.

Cosponsored with the Cornell Feline Health Center and Cat’s Pajamas, a fun store for kids and kids at heart, located in the DeWitt Mall in downtown Ithaca.  Please note: 10% of the proceeds will go to the SPCA of Tompkins County. Recommended for all ages! We also recommend buying your tickets in advance at CornellCinemaTickets.com

description: Join us for a FREE screening of an early masterpiece by 2-time Oscar winning director Asghar Farhadi, the Iranian filmmaker who boycotted the recent Academy Awards ceremony in protest of Trump's January executive order that temporarily banned entry to the U.S. by Iranians and six other Muslim-majority countries, which Farhadi called "inhumane." He was awarded his second Oscar for Best Foreign Language Film for The Salesman on February 26th, having previously won for A Separation in 2012. About Elly (2009), only released in the U.S. after the success of A Separartion, tells the story of a seaside reunion of old college friends that takes a mysterious turn when Elly (a friend of a friend brought along for a blind date), suddenly vanishes. Seemingly trivial lies, which started accumulating from the moment the group arrived at the seashore, unexpectedly swing round and come back full force. "Outstanding. A subtle psychological thriller." (The Guardian) The film will be introduced by Senior Lecturer Iago Gocheleishvili from the Department of Near Eastern Studies, a cosponsor of the screening, in addition to the Iranian Graduate Students Organization.

venue.about: Cornell Cinema has been cited as one of the best campus film exhibition programs in the country, screening close to 150 different films/videos each year, five nights a week in the beautiful Willard Straight Theatre.
venue.name: Cornell Cinema

description: Do you have a well-planned fitness routine? Do your weekly workouts address all the components of fitness? description:
Tompkins County Festivals Program Presents:

2017 FREE Event Planning Workshops
WEEK 2 - Wednesday, March 22, 2017
9:00 - 3:00PM at Cinemapolis Movie Theatre in Downtown Ithaca

Who should attend?
-  Individuals and groups applying for STPB Room Tax grant funding
-  Any event planners looking to do projects in 2017
-  Groups and organizations interested in considering new events or growing existing ones
-  Any one interested in learning more about event coordinator responsibilities and planning.

Workshop Goals:
Provide event planners in Tompkins County with topical, timely, and useful information on various aspects of event planning. Enable event planners to learn new ideas and share information with each other about challenges and solutions in the event planning process.  Help event planners be better prepared and organized for the event they are organizing. Inspire event planners to think about how their events can have a positive tourism impact on the community.

WEEK 2:   
Tompkins County Festivals Program Presents:
2017 Event Planning Boot Camp
Wednesday, March 22nd

A FREE & Informative Event!
at Cinemapolis Theatre
 

8:45AM - 9:00AM   CHECK-IN
Coffee & Tea compliments of Tompkins Festivals Program

MORNING MODULE -  9:00AM - 12:00PM


9:00AM - 10:00AM
IMPROVING YOUR TOURISM IMPACT
The Tompkins County Tourism Program supports many events in this area with the primary goal to draw more visitors to Tompkins County. How can you enhance your event to increase the likelihood of overnight stays and secondary spending in this community? This workshop will discuss formatting your event to attract visitors and increase tourism to the county.  
Speakers:
Laura Winter Falk - Owner, Experience the Finger Lakes | Livia Isaacson - Marketing Specialist, Ithaca Convention & Visitors Bureau | Sarah Imes - Sales Manager, Ithaca Convention & Visitors Bureau

10:00AM - 11:00AM
CREATING INCLUSIVE EVENTS & PROGRAMMING 
A workshop with Brave Trainings LLC Founder, Cornell F. Woodson on how to achieve inclusivity in your events from design to implementation. Participants will walk away with language and a basic understanding of how to monitor your programming to ensure you are producing thoughtful and welcoming experiences and environments. 

This workshop is a great opportunity to have staff and colleagues attend. For more information about Cornell's diversity trainings visit http://bravetrainings.com  


11:00AM - 12:00PM
THE HEALTH DEPARTMENT & YOUR EVENT - (Pending Availability )  
Learn firsthand from a County Health Department representative about the rules and regulations pertaining to food vendors and food service at your event.  Learn the required permits, deadlines, and checkpoints when it comes to planning mass gathering events.
Speaker: 
Rene Borgella, Jr. -  Public  Health Sanitarian, Tompkins County Health Department


12:00PM - 1:00PM
LUNCH BREAK
Lunch compliments of Tompkins Festivals Program

AFTERNOON MODULE - 1:00-3:00PM

1:00PM - 1:45PM 
MARKETING & ADVERTISING
What is the best way to get the word out about your special event? How soon should you start promoting your event, where, and how? This workshop will weigh in on the merits of print, radio, online advertising, press releases strategies, etc.  And also give you a realistic timelines for creating an integrated marketing campaign to promote your event.
Speakers:
Allison Graffin - Marketing Director, Downtown Ithaca Alliance


1:45PM - 2:30PM 
HOW DO YOU MEASURE SUCCESS? Event evaluation, winding down your event and preparing for the following year. 
By what measure was your event a success? Attendance? Draw? Who came to your event and how did they find out about your event? How do you gauge popular opinion? This seminar will detail why event evaluation is critical to the longevity of your event, and how to use it to your advantage going forward. If you have received a grant for your event this workshop is particularly good to attend. 
Speakers:
Tom Knipe - Senior Planner /  Tourism Coordinator - Tompkins County | Darlynne Overbaugh, Wizarding Weekend | 


2:30PM - 3:00PM
Technical Support - OPEN Q+A
Take this time to ask any follow up questions that apply specifically to your event one on one with Tatiana! Please come prepared with any questions as we’ll allot approximately 5min per attendee and schedule follow up meetings if necessary.
Speakers:
Tatiana Sy - Special Events Director at Downtown Ithaca

New event planners are encouraged to attend both workshop days.  Intermediate and professional organizers with experience are welcome to attend both as well, but may find the March 22nd workshop to be most valuable.

These workshops are FREE to attend.  Complimentary continental breakfast & lunch provided for attendees each day.  We will also offer parking vouchers for anyone parking in the Green St. and Seneca Garage for the day.



RSVP HERE: https://goo.gl/forms/cdy0DP3dSC25UIM63

description:
Don't Call Me Son (2016): Thurs, 3/2 @ 7pm & Sun, 3/5 @ 4:30pm:
Brazil's Anna Muylaert (The Second Mother) returns with an "endearingly performed story of a cross-dressing teenage boy who finds out he was stolen at birth, and is then forced to move in with his wealthy biological parents." (Hollywood Reporter) "The turmoil of adolescence is plumbed with wit and compassion... newcomer Naomi Nero defies expectations as a broodingly intense, potentially volcanic six-footer in stiletto heels." (Film Forum) (1 hr 22 min)
More at zeitgeistfilms.com/film/dontcallmeson
Watch a trailer here:
Don't Call Me Son - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JAh_fsFY-bY

Being 17 (2016): Thurs, 3/9 & Sun, 3/12 @ 7pm:
Director/writer André Téchiné (Wild Reeds) teams up with co-writer Sciamma (Girlhood) to depict "the awakening of gay adolescent desire and self-knowledge in this drama set in the French Pyrenees... an ultra-naturalistic slice of rocky adolescent life that combines violence and sensuality, wrenching loss and tender discovery." (Hollywood Reporter) (1 hr 56 min)
More at strandreleasing.com/films/being-17
Watch a trailer here:
Being 17 - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u4odOwOIH70

Cosponsored with the LGBT Resource Center & FGSS

venue.name: Cornell Cinema

name: LGBTQ+ Films: Don't Call Me Son & Being 17!

description:
Cornell Cooperative Extension of Tompkins County Presents
AgStravaganza!
Saturday, April 1, 2017, 10:00 AM - 4:00 PM
Ithaca Commons & Surrounding Streets

Saturday, April 1st from 10:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. the farm comes to the Ithaca Commons! Over 20 local direct marketing farms will fill the Commons, including Community Supported Agriculture (CSA), cheese, beer, flower, and meat operations. Come stroll the Commons and chat with farmers, sample their products, and find your farmer!

You can also check out some big farm equipment, watch some great agriculture videos, and talk to a plant scientist. The Tompkins County Dairy Princess will be joined by two of the State Princesses to serve Cornell Dairy ice cream samples and Polly-O cheese sticks, as well as offering the Wheel O’Dairy and their famous “Life is Cud” T-shirts!

Tompkins County 4-Her’s will be on hand to show and talk about their livestock, including a calf, sheep, bunnies, and poultry. They will be joined by members of the Dog Obedience Club throughout the event. You can also learn about other 4-H clubs and how to join one, and how to become an independent member. Rounding out the farm critter contingent will be Laughing Goat Fiber Farm, with some new lambs

CCE-Tompkins and Tompkins County Recycling are teaming up to help you learn more about reducing your waste stream, with on-site collection containers to help us manage the containers left over from ice cream and the tasty delights you will find from our local-food-focused food vendor, OmNomNomlettes.



Don't miss:

Ice cream with the Dairy Princess and spin the Wheel O'Dairy

 
Take in all our local farms have to offer from:

Sweet Land Farm

TC3 Farm

Heller's Farm

Interbrook Farm

Nook and Cranny Farm

Here We Are Farm

Plowbreak Farm

Full Plate Farms

Bandwagon Brewery

The Piggery

Laughing Goat

Sno* Farm Creamery

Scheffler Farm

Shelterbelt Farm

Spot Hollow Farm

Parulski Farms

Heaven Scent Farm

Shtayburne Farm

MacDonalds Farm

Glenwood Farms

 
PLUS: There will be tons of children’s activities: make a clothespin critter, plant a seed, make a cow puppet, play in the corn box, pet a bunny and check out baby chicks, watch some well-trained dogs at work! Everyone can learn what cows eat and about local foods, and if you are looking, find a farmer or some land with the LandLink folks!

This fun, educational event is sponsored by Tompkins County Farm Bureau in cooperation with CCE-Tompkins and the Downtown Ithaca Alliance. For more information contact Debbie Teeter at (607)272-2292 or dlt22@cornell.edu.

Fee:
FREE!

After the event is over head on over to State Theatre of Ithaca for Classic Movie: Field of Dreams at 7pm!

description:
Coltivare & the Finger Lakes Meat Project present: "Taste a Quarter": an afternoon of chef-prepared samples of locally-raised meat, cooking and butchering demonstrations, and interacting with local farmers. Learn how to save money by purchasing this high-quality, sustainable meat in bulk rather than by the cut, and taste samples prepared from more unfamiliar pieces of beef, pork, chicken, goat, and lamb.

This is an educational event rather than a farmers market; we invite you to chat with farmers about what they raise and how, and think about shifting the way you buy meat to reflect what's most convenient for farms & affordable for you: bulk purchasing.

 Local meat shouldn't be intimidating--it should be fun! Come down Sunday afternoon and fill your belly with delicious home-cooked goodness while learning more about the local food community.

REGISTER: http://bit.ly/tasteaquarter

The event fee is a $2-$5 self-determined suggested donation. We welcome anyone who wishes to attend; fees will be waived for any individuals or families who may wish to attend but for whom the entry fee would be a financial burden. No one will be asked to pay in order to enter.

description:
LACS Freedom School Flatbread Fundraiser at Agava Sunday March 19th

Have you heard of Goatboy?
This Old Time collaboration of players from The Horse Flies and the Evil City String Band brings Ithaca's finest musicians together at Agava on Sunday March 19th 4-6pm for the Freedom School Flatbread Fundraiser and Silent Auction. 

Hear Judy Hyman, Richie Stearns, Jeff Claus, Steve Selin  and more band together to support the Akwesasne Freedom School -- a Mohawk immersion school that has a 20+ year cultural exchange with LACS (Lehman Alternative Community School). All proceeds go to building projects at the Freedom School that LACS and AFS folks will work on together in May. 

Suggested donation of $10-$15 per person gains you access to this afternoon of great music and silent auction fun. Guests are encouraged to enjoy dinner at Agava during the show.  Agava donates $5 from every woodfired Flatbread Pizza ordered, so come hungry. Nia:wen / Thank you in advance for coming!

At 6PM, the second of our three-part series "Have You Ever Wondered...?" will take a look at how some artworks came to Cornell, how the art market shifts over time, and some of the legal and ethical concerns of museum collections. 

Admission to the Museum and these events is free!

description:
Nerd Nite is for all you thirsty fun geeks looking for something to get nerdy about "be there and be square" on Tuesday's once a month at Agava.  Shenanigans start at 8:30pm and dinner is served until 10.  Look for food and drink features at the bar when you arrive.

What this is . . . https://nerdnite.com/
We all know that learning is more fun when you’re drinking with friends and colleagues. Thus, Nerd Nite is a monthly event held in more than 90 cities across the globe during which several folks give 18-21-minute fun-yet-informative presentations across all disciplines – while the audience drinks.

Topics March 21st at 8:30PM

-Michelle White with a special introduction

-Kate Holden with "Get a Clue: Women in Detective Fiction" an investigative presentation that will discuss how women writers and female characters are changing the canonical understanding of the genre. 

-Andrea Bruns with "Incest, Exclusivity, and Your Least Favorite Cookie." Andrea will teach us about the fig wasp, which spends almost the entirety of its scandalously sheltered life within the confines of a single fig "fruit." This structured plant and pollinator mutualism tracks a murky history of coevolution.

description:
More than 750,000 young immigrants who arrived in the United States as children and are protected by the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) policy now face possible policy changes from a new presidential administration.

In an effort to clarify possible new practices, four Cornell administrators and faculty members will address the facts and uncertainty in a panel discussion, “Immigration Chaos: DACA Students and Higher Education Grapple With Upheaval,” Friday, March 17, at noon in Kennedy Hall’s David L. Call Alumni Auditorium.

The event is free and open to all.
Panelists will discuss the impact of immigration policy on DACA at the higher education, local and national levels. They are:

Barbara Knuth, senior vice provost and dean of the Graduate School, who administers undergraduate enrollment through the Undergraduate Admissions Office and the Office of Financial Aid and Student Employment, and serves on the University Diversity Council;  
                           
Carlos M. Gonzalez, executive director, Office of Academic Diversity Initiatives, who oversees key central academic support programs and grants, with a primary focus on academic success for underrepresented students of color, first generation, low-income and undocumented students;

Barbara Knuth, senior vice provost and dean of the Graduate School, who administers undergraduate enrollment through the Undergraduate Admissions Office and the Office of Financial Aid and Student Employment, and serves on the University Diversity Council;

Estelle McKee, clinical professor of law, who co-teaches Cornell Law School’s Asylum and Convention Against Torture Appellate Clinic, and has worked as an immigration attorney; and

Vijay Pendakur, the Robert W. and Elizabeth C. Staley Dean of Students.

The panel will be moderated by Rebecca Stoltzfus, vice provost for undergraduate education and professor of nutritional sciences.
President Barack Obama signed DACA in 2012 to protect undocumented children brought to the United States. Recent immigration actions by the Trump administration have created uncertainty about the future of the DACA program.

The panel discussion is presented by the Division of University Relations’ Diversity Council.

venue.about: Cornell University is an Ivy League university located in Ithaca, New York, USA
venue.name: Cornell University

name: DACA Students and Higher Education Grapple With Upheaval

description:
Due to the snowstorm Martha is not able to travel to Ithaca for this event. We are working to reschedule with her and will announce a new date as soon as possible. 
***
Artist Martha Rosler has been working in video, photography, and more since the late 1960s. Known for work that focuses on the public sphere from a feminist point of view, her seminal 1975 video "Semiotics of the Kitchen" is screening in conjunction with the exhibition "Empathy Academy: Social Practice and the Problem of Objects." She'll speak about her work tonight at a talk supported in part by a member of Cornell's Class of 1949 in honor of Jason and Clara Seley.

The Museum is open Thursday until 7:30 PM. Admission to the Museum and this Artist's Talk is free.

description:
This panel features speakers whose work covers different facets of the growing wellness industry. Panelists will give short presentations on how they are integrating wellness into the hospitality industry, followed by a question and answer session led by Rohit Verma who serves as the Dean of External Relations for the Cornell SC Johnson College of Business and the Executive Director of Cornell Institute for Healthy Futures.

Speakers:
Emilie Goudey, Canyon Ranch
Michelle Hocking MMH’10, Google
Neil Jacobs, Six Senses Hotel Resorts Spas
Mary Tabacchi, Professor Emerita
Moderator: Rohit Verma, Cornell SC Johnson College of Business

Hotel Ezra Cornell’s many speakers and panels are open to all students, faculty, and guests. See our full conference schedule cornellhec.com.

venue.about:
"Showcasing Hospitality Education Through Student Leadership"

The 92nd Annual Hotel Ezra Cornell
March 16-19th, 2017
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY
venue.name: Hotel Ezra Cornell

name: HEC 92: Wellness Panel

description:
Visit us this Sunday for a great show by Sixteen Feathers Savannah &Evan Williams bringing you a mixture of Ithaca style folk, rock, country and blues during Agava Brunch. It is a wonderful time for family and friends to enjoy a great meal and wonderful entertainment. 
Join us a little early before the show and enjoy bottomless mimosas to your heart’s content! New York State Liquor Authorities have finally lifted the Sunday alcohol ban. Drink in celebration with bottomless mimosas from 10am–12pm every Sunday during brunch.

Want to play at Agava? Jon Kaplan hosts Open Mic Night every Monday! Come in and perform your favorite songs whether it’s a cover or an original piece. All ages, instruments, and ensembles are welcome! Sign-ups start at 7:30 pm, the show beings at 8:30 pm. All performers will receive a complimentary free draft beer (the younger crowd gets dessert).

For all other music inquiries, contact Ian at agavamusic@gmail.com. See you all soon!

venue.about: AGAVA is a Southwest-Inspired restaurant, on Ithaca's East Hill
venue.name: AGAVA

name: Live Music: Sixteen Feathers

description: Weekdays 8-6, Saturday 10-5, and online! Two snow days turned into over a week-long extension on Grad Fair specials for the Class of 2017. Shop in-store or online for 25% off diploma frames (lowest price of the year!) and 25% off Cornell Class of 2017 pennants, caps, tees, glassware and more. Plus there are special gifts when you order personalized graduation announcements or a Cornell class ring. As of 3/16 there are only 73 days until graduation!

venue.about: The official Cornell University store, celebrating everything Cornell & helping you succeed.  store.cornell.edu
venue.name: The Cornell Store

name: Cornell Grad Fair Snow Days Extension

description: Come early for dinner or join us for drinks this evening to listen to live music featuring jazz and blues - The Diana Leigh Trio includes Diana on vocals, Jesse Collins on alto saxophone, and Jim Scarpulla on keyboards.  The trio plays jazz and blues in an intimate yet complex presentation. Jesse's obbligatos behind Diana's singing creates a richness and depth, as inspired by Prez & Billie.

venue.name: AGAVA

name: Live Music: Diana Leigh Trio
